reviewText: I want to echo what other reviews have said. This is a great series for all ages. It is a truely well written and well paced exposition of the process of growing up, making and keeping friends, and accepting a place in the world. Ang starts out as a kid who just wants to play and gradually over the series discovers how to be a responsible productive person. The side and back stories are also uplifting and instructive. Good for all ages. Most of the other things on Nick and CTV have devolved to cheap idiot food that has no art or story line. Kudos to whoever thought this series up.
Title: Avatar: The Last Airbender: Book 1: Water, Vol. 1 (Checkpoint)

reviewText: This an excellently written series. Even though it written for kids, it doesn't insult the intelligence of either the kids or the adults watching it. It will keep all viewers engaged.

reviewText: I can remember the first time catching the show on accident on Nickelodeon--I was channel surfing and came across this strange cartoon I had never seen before.  One that had a blue arrow on his head.  I thought to myself, wow, that's silly.  But I kept the show on and gave it a chance.  The more I watched, the more my interest grew.  So I watched it a few more times and to my great satisfaction and surprise, I think I've found a show to look forward to.Long ago existed an Avatar who was a master of bending the four great elements of the world--Water, Earth, Fire, and Air.  But then the Fire Nation waged war and havoc, wanting control and power over the world.  The only being who can save and unite the four nations again is the Avatar!  But when the world went searching for him, he disappeared for one hundred years, and war has reigned ever since.  By striking chance, a practicing water bender, Katara, and her brother Sokka, discover the new Avatar, Aang, who was frozen in ice since the disappearance of the last Avatar.  To much surprise, it is only a 12 year old boy!  Katara's and Sokka's destiny is now to help Aang find teachers to train Aang so he can master bending the four elements to restore peace in the world.  With the help of Momo, a fun white lemur, and his giant flying bison Appa, Aang sets his journey ahead of him with his new friends, which later he recognizes as his family.  But running after the Avatar is the banished Fire Nation prince, Zuko, who plans to capture the Avatar; something his father was never able to do.  By capturing the Avatar, Zuko hopes to restore his honor and respect from his people, and more importantly, respect from his father.I like this show because of its simple and kid-like nature.  Aang likes to have fun, even when it means having fun when he has the whole world depending on him to save the world.  His simple and open mind lead him into disasters and adventures, but he always comes out unharmed and with a new experience in which to learn from.  And when he and his friends are most in need, he's as dependable as they come.  I like the nature of a kid having fun and being simple minded, without the constant worries most adults seem to have in their lives.  This show examples why it is important not to forget to have fun, and that being just a kid, no matter how old, is ok to be sometimes.  The only drawback of the DVD is a common one amongst the other reviewers, in that there are only 4 episodes.  Fortunate for me, I discovered the show later than its premiere, so all the shows on the disc were new except Chapter 4.  But of course, I'd like to see more.  Four shows for me is just not enough!  Besides that, I'd recommend the show to both adults and children.  Nickelodeon has surprised me by airing a show like this on their station, as I don't recall ever having seen anime on it before (though I know there was a way while back), or any other show like this at all.  If you haven't seen Nickelodeon's Avatar: The Last Airbender, I'd highly suggest it.  It's entertaining and every story leaves you feeling good after watching.
summary: Nickelodeon's Big Surprise is the Avatar!
Title: Avatar: The Last Airbender: Book 1: Water, Vol. 1 (Checkpoint)

reviewText: I don't see many reviews for this episode but rather for the entire season.This is a good episode.  We are introduced to Azula, a devious, borderline insane, power-hungry, sister of Zucko.  This is also the episode where we learn a little bit more about the Avatar state, hence the name.  Aang now has to be rather careful when he goes into the Avatar state, for if he dies, game over.  But what really shines in this episode is Iroh and Zucko.While this wasn't the official beginning of Zucko's transformation, it marks the beginning of his desire to find his own path and uncle Iroh is right there, willing to guide this brash young boy into a far better man.  I only wish I had had an uncle like Iroh.  The plot development for Aang is not as extensive as it is for Zucko and this being my second time through, this was also the point in the story where I started to care more about Zucko than Aang and co.This episode is good, but not great.  Mostly just groundwork being laid that will reach fruition much later in the season and series.  I truly do wish they would have allowed this series to go more than 3 years.  Instead they destroy it's legacy with the Legend of Korrah or whatever they call it.  That serious was a cross between Avatar and Fight Club.Opinions aside, this season is kicked off nicely, leaving one wanting more.
Title: Avatar: The Last Airbender: Book 1: Water, Vol. 1 (Checkpoint)

reviewText: We love love love Avatar!  We've been watching since my youngest was about 3.  It's a show I never tire of, even though it's still on every day.  Not in order though, so of course I had to buy it when I realized it was on DVD.  My kids are now 6, 7 and 16 and still love it even though we've seen the episodes over and over.  My husband and I will watch even after the kids go to bed, lol.  It's always "just one more episode..." until we force ourselves to turn it off.  Everyone I've suggested it to has totally fallen for it - I can't recommend it enough!

reviewText: I am a huge fan of Japanese anime, because anime usually has an amazing storyline, great and loveable characters and developement, plus beautiful animation and music to boot! Modern cartoons here..."cardboard style" animation and lame or random plotline. But "Avatar: The Last Airbender" not only has an awesome storyline, but just like anime, has loveable characters and developement, beautiful animation, and the music is actually quite nice at times. It's about a brother and sister, Sokka and Katara, who discover a boy whose been frozen in ice for 100 years named Aang and his flying pet Appa. He not only is the only Airbender left, but also the next Avatar, one with the ability to bend all four elements! For a kids show (rated Y7), this story has depth! It's clean, it's fun, it's engaging....I think we have a winner!
summary: If there's such a thing as American anime, this is it!

reviewText: Most western animation for children is, to put it simply, really wretched. At best, it's tolerable.But a shining exception would be the tale of the Avatar of all four elements, and to restore the balance in the world. "Avatar The Last Airbender - Book 1 Water, Vol. 1" serves as a solid start to the series -- it smoothly introduces the characters and sets up some nice story arcs, without skimping on development of either.South Pole Water Tribe siblings Katara and Sokka stumble across a glowing iceberg with a young Airbender boy named Aang (and his flying bison) inside. All Airbenders were killed long ago. You guessed it (and so does Katara): Aang is the Avatar who mysteriously vanished a century ago, even though he has yet to master Earth, Water and Fire. And, uh, he's a total goofball.Unfortunately, a Fire Nation prince named Zuko has been wandering the world in search of Aang, and agrees to let the Water Tribe alone if Aang surrenders. Of course, Katara and Sokka set out to rescue their friend, and since Katara isn't experienced enough in waterbending to teach Aang, they set out for the North Pole to find a waterbending master.But along the way they run into new problems -- first Aang returns to his old Temple and finds it in ruins, with all the Airbenders dead. Then the three visit Kyoshi Island, where the female warriors take exception to Sokka's sexism, and Aang starts getting a bit full of himself. Meanwhile, Zuko's quest is put in jeopardy when an arrogant general challenges him to a firebending duel.The highest compliment I can pay "Avatar: The Last Airbender" is that it's like a thoroughly solid action/fantasy anime. Even though "Book 1, Water: Volume 1" is only the first few episodes of the series, it's pretty obvious that this is not a simple kid's show -- it's got good writing, excellent animation, and a general look rawn from Asian and Inuit cultures.The first episode is a bit lackluster -- there's a bit too much of Aang goofing around, riding penguins and exploring old battleships, as well as some gross-out humor. But things tart gelling with the explosive fight scenes and grim confrontations of the second episode, especially since we really get to know the Prince Zuko there and get a glimpse of the Fire Nation' power.And the whole quest-storyline has become nice and tight by the third and fourth episodes, even as our heroes stop for one-off stories. There's plenty of action and explosive fire-battles (particularly Zuko's brilliant battle with the sneering Zhao), but the writers never quite forget to include some comedy (riding the elephant koi) and character development.And they do a good job with the characters -- Aang soon proves himself a kind and selfless kid, but still a kid. And we get to see some of his inner turmoil when he revisits his old home to find it a snowed-in, abandoned ruin, and his old master Monk Gyatso gone.Katara and Sokka round out the cast, and are the required bickering siblings -- Katara is short-fused but sensible, and Sokka is rather swelled-headed although it's soon clear that he's courageous and means well. And though he's the antagonist, scarred teenager Zuko is excellent -- his quest obviously has deeper motives behind it, and he clearly isn't a bad person."Avatar The Last Airbendeer's" first volume is a fairly smooth introduction to a solid action/fantasy series, and a good setup to an outstanding show. A bit wobbly at first, but it quickly picks up steam.
Title: Avatar: The Last Airbender: Book 1: Water, Vol. 1 (Checkpoint)

reviewText: I understand that the consensus out there is that cartoons are for kids, but what about us adults? Well, this series draws in the standard young viewer, but there is enough here for adults like me to get excited about, too. The story of the Avatar is absolutely awesome. The characters are cool, but also can be very powerful. The enemy is just as interesting as the heroes. And while there are some silly moments, there are also moments of great action, intensity, and a genuine seriousness to the show. In fact, this show's greatest strength is it's outstanding ability to balance great humor with a wonderful and serious story. Also, each episode leads into the next one, so like a soap opera, you get hooked on what happens next. Finally, what can I say about the animation? Beautiful, beautiful, beautiful.Did I mention the awesome fighting sequences?So yes, the kids out there will love this show, and for good reason. But for once, something is being shown on Nick that allows the little kid in all of us adults to get excited, too! HIGHLY RECOMMENDED!!
summary: Finally, an animated series that adults can like, too!!
Title: Avatar: The Last Airbender: Book 1: Water, Vol. 1 (Checkpoint)

reviewText: This series is great for kids and their parents. It consistently delivers great plotting, action and laughs. If only the live action movie had worked harder to capture the tone of the animated series, maybe there would have been a second film to cover this season.
summary: Second verse, same as the first!

reviewText: Hey there!  Lauren here.  I LOVE Avatar: The Last Airbender and I recommend it to anyone who is looking for something new and exciting to watch.  It's dramatic, suspenseful and very enjoyable to watch.  It's full of adventure as well.In a time when the world is divided into four nations:  Water tribes, earth kingdoms, fire nation and air nomads, it seems peaceful.  But that all changes when the greedy and power hungry fire nation starts a war with the other three nations.  The world's only hope is the Avatar, a boy who can master the bending disciplines of all four elements.  But he hasn't been seen for a hundred years.  It's not until a waterbender named Katara and her annoying older brother, Sokka, free Aang from an iceburg, do they uncover the world's last hope.  Now it's up to Aang to learn all four bending disciplines in order to end the war and bring balance back to the world.  With the help of Katara and Sokka, Aang will learn a lot more than the bending arts. He will learn what true friendship is.Water, earth, fire air.Long ago, the four nations lived together in harmonyThen everything changed when the fire nation attackedOnly the Avatar, master of all four elements could stop themBut when the world needed him most, he vanishedA hundred years passed and my brother and I discovered the new Avatar.  An airbender named Aang.  And although his airbending skills are great, he has a lot to learn before he's ready to save anyoneBut I believe, Aang can save the worldJoin Katara, her annoying brother, Sokka and their friend, Aang, as they make their way to the North Pole in search of a waterbending teacher for Katara.  Also, As the Avatar, Aang must master all four elements in order to defeat the fire lord and restore balance to the world.I've been watching this show for nine months now and I LOVE it.  Katara is my favorite character and I believe Mae Whitman portrays her really well.  I LOVE this show and I can't wait till it comes to DVD.  Like Katara, my element is also water.  I identify with Katara the most.May the power of water, earth, fire and air be with everyone always.
summary: Soar to new heights and adventure with Avatar The Last Airbender
Title: Avatar: The Last Airbender: Book 1: Water, Vol. 1 (Checkpoint)

reviewText: The best cartoon ever! it doesn't matter how many times you watch it you will love it. I must say that this season was a little bit less exciting than Season 3

reviewText: Okay, I started watching Avatar when it first started airing, but I started to get forgetful and stopped watching it.  Well, I just rented this, and I have to admit, I am becoming a fan.  This show is a ton of fun to watch!  Nowadays, the only other Nick show you can say that about is Spongebob, which I have watched since it first aired in '99, and it's starting to lose it's charm.  Literally all of Nick's new show ideas have sucked, but this is a real find.Basically, if you're 9-12, you'll love it.If you're 13-25, you'll still enjoy it.For once in a long time, Nick has started something that the whole family can enjoy.  Let's just hope they don't screw it up.
summary: Let it be known: This is NOT just a kid's show!!
Title: Avatar: The Last Airbender: Book 1: Water, Vol. 1 (Checkpoint)

reviewText: This is literally the best serialized cartoon made by Americans in the past 10 years.  Michael Dimartino & Bryan Konietzko have created a fantasy world modeled after Asian nations and culture, full of martial arts magic.Aang is the Avatar, the last of his race (the Airbenders).  As Avatar he is capable of harnessing the four elements that govern their world and keep the peace between the four races (one per element) that populate the world.  Shortly after learning his destiny as Avatar, Aang runs away from the responsiblity.  Near to death after a becoming lost in a seastorm, Aang becomes sealed in ice for a hundred years.He is set free by Katara and Sokka, who eventually become his traveling companions.  Katara is a young untrained waterbender that is a driving force for Aang's change towards responsibility.  In turn, Aang helps Katara to have more fun.  After a time, Katara becomes his waterbending master.  Sokka is responsible in his own way as well, but ends up as almost comic relief for some of the more emotionally charged scenes.Additional characters appear and stay with the series.  Prince Zuko is almost a foil for Aang at first before being shown as a more parallel character.  He travels with his Uncle, Iroh.  Zuko's sister and father, Fire Lord Ozai, tend to be the antagonists in the second book.  All are fire nation (the bad guys) but we see in both Zuko and Iroh that that fact does not automatically make them evil heartless killers.In book two we meet Toph, a blind earthbender girl who doesn't want her family to know that she's a capable bender.  She becomes Aang's earthbending master, and is quite a tough teacher despite her apparent handicap of blindness.The characters are memorable and well-developed.  The plot line is terrific with many different possiblities of how things could turn out. This is not a cartoon that cops out on sadness or death.  Avatar is not like some of the magical girl cartoons from Japan where people die and then in the next season or episode are right back up and kicking.  Avatar is a better reflection of real life.  When people die (and it's not always bad guys doing the dying) they do not come back. And sometimes the good guys do bad things either because they didn't have all the information or because there didn't seem to be any other alternative.  Hard lessons like truth, justice and good triumphant aren't always learned the first time.It's really a great cartoon for people of all ages and every stage of life.
summary: Flat out the best cartoon in America
Title: Avatar: The Last Airbender: Book 1: Water, Vol. 1 (Checkpoint)

reviewText: We love watching all the episodes of Avatar the Last Airbender. This is a show that the whole family watched and loves.

reviewText: At least Zuko is reunited with his uncle, but what a bittersweet reunion it is. As in Season 1, Zuko is impatient to master Firebending, and wants to reach the level his sister is at (Azula really is a prodigy!) but Zuko becomes frustrated and angry - this episode is deservedly called Bitter Work not just because of what Zuko and Iroh have to deal with, but also Aang's struggle to learn Earthbending.

Title: Avatar: The Last Airbender: Book 1: Water, Vol. 1 (Checkpoint)

reviewText: Okay! I'll confess! I am 41 years old and I love this show! I was at a friend's house a few months ago, and his 10 year old daughter was totally hooked on this show. I watched one episode with her just to show that I was a caring uncle-type guy I was. It was funny! It was like anime...but strangely not Japanese in style. The kids were smart and brave and realistic. The show was funny and very charming. Once I saw Appa (Aang's giant flying Bison) I was hooked!My friend's daughter wanted to watch another episode. They had them all on Tivo. Next thing you know, there are 3 of us adults and only the one kid watching the show, and I don't know who was enjoying it more!I think my favorite episode is the one where Aang, who was frozen in ice for 100 years, runs into his childhood friend Bumi. It is a very funny episode, and begins the onslaught against one poor farmer who is forever getting his cabbage cart run into by somebody. He appears in later episodes as well, and his plaintive cry of "My cabbages!" is like a great parody of the dreaded "fruit cart" cliche in live action films. This is the cliche that appears in nearly every chase scene where suddenly out of nowhere the ubiquitous fruit cart appears and the all the drivers crash into it.There is fun, and there is responsibility. Yin and yang. It makes for a great show.
summary: I Have A Confession to Make...
Title: Avatar: The Last Airbender: Book 1: Water, Vol. 1 (Checkpoint)

reviewText: Who would have thought that a cartoon would become the one and only show that no one in our family wants to miss?  Of course Avatar is much more sophisticated than Bugs Bunny or Spongebob.The characters are unique and well-developed.  The story is compelling.  The setting is a blend of Asian cultures and magic.  It shows the best in people overcoming the worst situations with grace and humor.  And it's exciting...  battles fought on land, air and water.Each show moves the story along a little further toward the ultimate conclusion -- which I hope is a very long time in coming!Highly, highly recommended for all ages.
summary: The Show That Has Our Whole Family Watching
Title: Avatar: The Last Airbender: Book 1: Water, Vol. 1 (Checkpoint)

reviewText: It is hard to believe but Volume II is even better than Volume I.  How?  Well the humor is even funnier - though young children probably won't 'get' all of it - and the drama is increased.  Particularly striking are the flashbacks of Prince Zuko as he looks back on his childhood, the loss of family members, and the craziness of his sister.Five Stars.  Still one of the best family series out there.  Humor, drama, friendship and adventure.  The story becomes more layered and the characters more developed.  Who would have thought it could have gotten even better!Pam T~
summary: Absolutely Top Notch Entertainment - a review of Avatar, Volume 2
Title: Avatar: The Last Airbender: Book 1: Water, Vol. 1 (Checkpoint)

reviewText: Watching Avatar has become a ritual for us, one episode, then two, after dinner; I've never seen my wife so excited about a movie or series... It's really great fun for all ages (5-40 in this case)!
Title: Avatar: The Last Airbender: Book 1: Water, Vol. 1 (Checkpoint)

reviewText: Let me say first of all that I love this show. There are very few shows that my whole family will sit down and watch at the same time, and Avatar: The Last Airbender is one of them. The story of Aang and his friends trying to reach the North Pole so he can begin his quest for mastery of the four elements by learning Water Bending (to go with his Air Bending mastery), is not only very well done, its cool for both kids and adults. Based loosely on Chinese/Japanese mythology and martial arts, the character/creature designs are interesting, the action is always great, but not at the expense of the smaller moments, and the funny moments as well.What I don't like in Nickelodeon only including the first 4 episodes on the first release. Why not release the whole first season? I understand this way is probably more price friendly for parents who's kiddos love the show, but it seems like they are trying to squeeze us for everything they can. But other than that, I'm planning on buying all the discs and can give this release my highest recommendation.
summary: Love the show, don't love the Nick squeezing....
Title: Avatar: The Last Airbender: Book 1: Water, Vol. 1 (Checkpoint)

reviewText: My son loves this show.  I think it is age appropriate with out being too violent and it is entertaining for my husband as well.

Title: Avatar: The Last Airbender: Book 1: Water, Vol. 1 (Checkpoint)

reviewText: This season is where Avatar: The Last Airbender really finds its footing and produces the best story arc of the show. We learn a lot more about the characters' motivation and backstory, we meet Toph, my favorite character in the entire series, and Aang and friends learn more about what they need to do to defeat the Fire Nation. We explore the Earth Kingdom, and fetch up in the mysterious city of Ba Sing Se, a city of walls and secrets where not everything is as it seems. But the Fire Nation is not far behind…In Season 1, things take a while to get started. Season 3 has some excellent episodes in it, but is fairly uneven. But season 2, and the latter half of Season 2 in particular, is the best of Avatar's three seasons—effectively, the "Empire Strikes Back" of the Avatar trilogy. It does have a couple of so-so episodes—most notably "Avatar Day" and "The Swamp"—but it gets those out of the way early on and focuses on greatness. The last half of the season is a suspenseful thrill ride with more twists than a spiral notebook, and will leave you wondering how they managed to get away with such amazing storytelling in a kids' show.
summary: The "Empire Strikes Back" of Avatar: The Last Airbender
Title: Avatar: The Last Airbender: Book 1: Water, Vol. 1 (Checkpoint)

reviewText: I have to say this animated series really surprised me. I enjoyed the movie so I thought I'd give the animated series a look so glad I did. Now it has some violence but it is FANTASY based so to those nay Sayers I say get over and let yourself enjoy the story. It has good vs. evil theme and redemption of a lost soul so the series portrays moral values. There are some laughs and sadness too. What I really enjoyed is they took the story to a conclusion, which we don't get due to ratings often. Again I found it to be an enjoyable watch during the winter doldrums.

reviewText: The story line and animation in this cartoon series is excellent! This cartoon series teaches children about Morals and the difference between right and wrong, also it teaches children the importance of being truthful not only to others but to yourself. True this cartoon series revolves around a war and shows hatred toward one "Tribe" of people named the "Fire Nation" but it also teaches children the importance of forgiveness and that the whole of a Nation is not exactly like the few that are in charge of that Nation are with their cruelty.I would highly recommend that you allow your children to watch the entire 3 seasons of this animated series.

Title: Avatar: The Last Airbender: Book 1: Water, Vol. 1 (Checkpoint)

reviewText: I didn't think it was possible, but they did it. An American team created an anime-stylized cartoon that is in every way better than any recent anime shows that have come out in the West. Avater really seems like a labor of love here. We have a wide, expansive plot, likeable characters, extremely well choreographed action, voice acting that's decent or, in the case of Mark Hamill as Fire Lord Ozai, incredible, and fantastic animation and color choices.There's really nothing not to love about this series. The fact that this show is performing so well even with older (college age!) viewers might be a signal to networks that if you let your shows have a little more freedom then you'll be rewarded. I won't hesitate to call Avatar the best animated show on TV at the moment, because unlike some of the anime that plays on Cartoon Network, Avatar appeals to all ages and isn't badly dubbed.There are funny parts, there are sad parts, and then there are just plain awesome parts to this show. It manages not to become formulaic (as some quest shows sometimes do) and each new episode continues the plot and expands the world. I don't think Avatar will stretch on forever, like some anime does, because the goal is in sight. It just takes the mastery of the four elements to be able to get there.With a third season in production, there's no reason not to buy these DVDs except for one: If Nickelodeon were smart they'd release season boxsets with all 20 episodes on 3 or 4 disks (double sided is fine as long as it minimizes costs) for an affordable $20-$35. Warner Bros. has done with their cartoons, and they've sold well. Anyway, hoping that this will happen, I still maintain that Avatar is an excellent cartoon which everyone can watch. It doesn't insult your intelligence and the action is amazing. Buy and watch this series to help keep supporting it until the end.
summary: Americans have created a Cartoon better than any anime out there.
Title: Avatar: The Last Airbender: Book 1: Water, Vol. 1 (Checkpoint)

Title: Avatar: The Last Airbender: Book 1: Water, Vol. 1 (Checkpoint)

reviewText: I wasn't too excited when nick was going to premier Avatar. I figured it was going to be another cheap japanese Anime wannabe cartoon (anime not made in japan) I decided to give it a shot. Superisingly it was really good! The artwork is beautiful, they got the anime style down really good. It has a good plotline too. This show isin't like anything currently on nick. I'm glad nick finially put on some good shows, (ever since invader zim, and other classic nick shows were canceled)Plotline, a brother (saka) and sister(katara), two water tribe members (ability to use an art to control water) find a 1000 year old glacier with a boy trapped inside. The glacier melts and the boy, who is named Ang, he doesn't remember anything, or that his Air bending tribe was detroyed and everyone was killed) Katara and Saka soon discover that Ang is the Avatar (a bender capable of learning all bending techniques Air, water, fire and Earth) Katara and Saka try to help him learn all the bending techniques to help save the world from a war caused by the fire nation. Prince kuzo, a fire nation prince who was banished by his father is trying to gain honor by capturing the Avatar, so he pretty much slows them down xDAnyways, this is a pretty good show so far. I took off one star because the show just draggs on forever. But it's a really good show and worth the watch.
Title: Avatar: The Last Airbender: Book 1: Water, Vol. 1 (Checkpoint)

reviewText: From my 3 year old to my wife and I we love to watch this series. We are practically wearing out the DVDs waiting for the next ones to emerge. It is an original story line with great character, voices, animation, action adventure and lessons of growing up.Fun and intrigue for the whole family that is so rare now days with lesser quality animations on the rise with little or no plot.This series sheds perspective on life's little problems and how to face them in a very entertaining way. The children will like the moment to moment action and the individual plot lines in each episode and the adults can enjoy the overall story arc and plot.Definitively a must in the family library.
Title: Avatar: The Last Airbender: Book 1: Water, Vol. 1 (Checkpoint)

reviewText: We absolutely loved the Avatar series. Each season was packed with adventure. It is a great show for kids. No swearing, children learning to deal with each other and life, and love and kindness winning out in the end. Would highly recommend this series!
